paragraphs.text: Fossil fuels are no catastrophe. They have made our lives better.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: People argue about whether the "consensus" of scientists is that we face disaster because of global warming
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Instead of debating whether man's greenhouse gasses will raise temperatures, we should argue about how we gauge disasters
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you take most environmentalists and climate scientists at their word
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the Earth heated up about 1.4 degrees Fahrenheit over the past century, not much more than it heated up the century before that
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Warming may increase
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: no one can be certain of that
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Let's agree for the sake of argument that this recent warming was partly caused by humanity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Let's also agree that there are some negative effects, including more frequent coastal flooding or longer droughts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we agree that those are costs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: shouldn't we also look at the benefits?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Much of modern civilization owes its existence to our use of the fossil fuels that produce the greenhouse gasses
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I don't see that civilization as misfortune
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I wish climate alarmists would weigh its accomplishments against the relatively small downsides of climate change
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One of industry's biggest accomplishments is creating a world where far fewer of us are likely to die because of weather
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Alex Epstein's book"The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels" documents the rapidly shrinking number of human beings killed by storms, floods and other climate events thanks largely to ever-growing industry, fueled mainly by oil, natural gas and coal
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: On "Stossel" my Fox Business Network TV show this week, he argues that if we compare conditions a century ago to conditions last year
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: we shouldn't obsess about how much carbon dioxide is in the air-- or whether Earth is warming
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: we should look at how much safer life became
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In 2013, "Climate-related deaths were at a record low -- in supposedly the worst climate in history-- under 30,000," says Epstein
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In 1931, bad weather killed 3 million people
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: You can argue that we get some things wrong as a civilization
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: thanks to our use of fossil fuels, we get something very right
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Epstein points out that humanity owes its current ability to survive harsh winters, arid deserts and other naturally -dangerous environments to the same fuels that activists now condemn
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "We have the luxury of being able to absorb a certain amount of climate-related damage so we can live in all of these cool places."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: His argument is unusual
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because environmentalists spread the idea that, without human interference, the planet is perfect
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: by what standard?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you went to someone 300 years ago and asked them, do you have a perfect climate?"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: they would think you were crazy, says Epstein
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "They were terrified of climate, because climate doesn't give you the resources that you need. It doesn't give you water when you need it. It doesn't give you the temperature when you need it."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It was once common to say that humans change their environment
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That shouldn't offend people today, says Epstein
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: We should be thrilled that humans "create technology to master climate.... That's why so few people today die from climate."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Epstein correctly says that instead of talking about "climate change" -- of which there will always be some, with or without human influence-- we should focus on "climate catastrophe," weather that actually kills people
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Those catastrophes, measured in lost lives, are getting rarer
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Most of the changes humans make to our environment are desirable changes that help us live longer and more comfortably
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "The dogma that man is ruining the planet rather than improving it is a religion, a source of prestige and a career for too many people."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we regard nature as pristine and think it must never be altered
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: we will have big problems
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We will die young and lead miserable, difficult lives
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I think of industry as something that is mostly very good for us, with a few minor side effects that aren't
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Fossil fuels are a little like antibiotics, says Epstein
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It's good to draw attention to minor side effects
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it would be crazy to abandon all treatment because of them
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Fossil fuels are no catastrophe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They contribute to health and a better life
paragraphs.label: assumption
